value: caption=An old airplane on display in Terminal 2 at Helsinki-Vantaa Airport

region in southern Finland, right north of
. Part of the Helsinki Metropolitan Area, it is the fourth most populous city in Finland. For practical purposes also the northern suburbs of Helsinki are included in this article.
, Vantaa is basically an extension of Helsinki and does not have one single city center. Vantaa's administrative center is in Tikkurila.
The city is indeed accessible by air, as Helsinki airport is situated in Vantaa. Moreover Helsinki's general aviation airport Malmi is located in northern Helsinki.
The main railroad north from Helsinki goes through Vantaa. In addition to several local train stations, all long distance trains to the north and east, including the ones to
, stop at Tikkurila station. If you are heading for the western parts of Vantaa, you can take the Vantaanlaakso local train line.

Freeways 3, 4, 45 and 7 out of Helsinki go through Vantaa and the main east-western road is the third ring road (Kehä III). The first ring road (Kehä I) is the main east-western road in northern Helsinki. In the morning and afternoon rush hours traffic it can get quite busy and in the winter a heavy snowfall or a larger accident due to the often over-frozen road surface can block the traffic completely.
From Helsinki several local buses go to Vantaa, and there are some lines directly from Espoo too. The Helsinki region public transport authority's
is an excellent tool to find out which bus you should take from one address to another. Some larger cities in southern Finland also have a direct connection to Helsinki airport.
If you are going north or south, local trains may be an option however not a useful as the bus. The

(Ring Line) connecting the main line with Vantaanlaakso via the airport is planned to be operational in 2015 and will greatly enhance the usability of rail travel in Vantaa as well as provide a rail link from the airport to central Helsinki.

Buses are the best form of public transport as there is a maze of bus lines in the area. Bus lines with three-digit numbers go across the city borders, more often than not terminating in one of central Helsinki's bus stations. Bus lines with two-digit numbers are internal lines, therefore there might be two different buses with the same number, one in Helsinki and one in Vantaa. If you are traveling across the city borders you will need a

(seutulippu, button "2" on the travel card reader), which is valid for all of Helsinki, Espoo and Vantaa and costs a little less than twice the price of a single zone ticket. As elsewhere in the Capital region tickets are valid for 80 minutes and include unlimited transfer. The price for a ticket in Vantaa is €3 (€1.95 if paying with a Travel Card), for Helsinki likewise €3 (€1.95 if paying with a Travel Card) and €5 for a regional ticket valid in both cities (€3,65 if paying with Travel Card).
As distances are longer than in the more central parts of Helsinki, driving is sometimes an option. As above, the traffic can get quite congested in the rush hours, especially on the ring roads.
On a sunny summer day you can make use of the cycle and footpaths crisscrossing Vantaa and suburban Helsinki. Get a good map.

value: content=Heureka is an interactive science museum, with different kinds of exhibitions about technology, physics, chemistry, medicine, astronomy and so on. Really exciting for children interested in science.
alt=Pyhän Laurin kirkko, Helsingin pitäjän kirkko
content=A medieval stone church from the 15th century in the southern part of Vantaa.
content=Near Helsinki-Vantaa airport. A museum with over 70 planes (both civilian and military) as well as plane parts, equipment and photos.
content=Completed in 1984, this church is pretty cubist on both the inside an outside.
content=Learn more about how Vantaa grew from a couple of farms at the outskirts of Helsinki to the city of 200 000 inhabitants it is today.
directions=In Koivuhaka district, just east of the airport
content=Not just a plant and gardening store, but actually a 3500 sq.m garden with an indoor desert where cacti grow and a Japanese garden mimicking the climate of Tokyo round the year.

content=It's hard to call this farmland dominated area at the eastern edge of Vantaa a "city district". In the summer it's a pleasant area for biking along the unpaved roads between the fields where sheep and cows graze. It's also not far away to Sipoonkorven kansallispuisto (Sipoonkorpi National Park) in the neighboring Sipoo municipality.

content=Located north of Malmi, the airport is nowadays the general aviation airport of Helsinki. Even if you aren't a pilot yourself, it's quite interesting to sit in the restaurant and watch small planes and helicopters land and take off.
content=A look into the daily life on a 18th century manor. Also hosts a restaurant and a riding school.
directions=Buses 650 and 615T from Helsinki Railway Station or bus 61 from Tikkurila Station
content=A big entertainment complex located near the airport in Vantaa, next to a large shopping mall Jumbo, just north of Helsinki. Biggest attractions are
with pretty cool and fast slides in the waterpark section and a large selection of relaxation pools, jacuzzis and different saunas in the other section, and

which is a glow in the dark 15-hole miniature golf course with over-the-top mechanized special effects and a special "horror" section. Cheesy but fun, especially after a few drinks from the bar. Other attractions in Flamingo include a small casino, a 3D movie theater, many pubs and restaurants, a variety of specialist shops, a large hotel and one of the biggest nightclubs in Finland called

content=This traditional smoke sauna is located in Vantaa but very easy to reach from Helsinki Railway Station. Situated in Kuusijärvi Outdoor Centre and besides a beautiful lake, it's widely regarded as one of the best traditional saunas in the capital region. Rebuilt in 2011.. Take your swim gear with you, as the smoke sauna is mixed-sex.
hours=Open by arrangement around the year.

content=A typical Finnish farm located in the village of Sotunki in eastern Vantaa and surrounded by a picturesque landscape. On the farm you can meet animals representing the traditional Finnish stock: cows, sheep, goats, pigs, horses and more..
content=A music festival of classic baroque music held in St. Lawrence church in Helsingin pitäjän kirkkokylä
hours=We, Fr and Sa nights in the summer
content=Dance tango and other similar dances. Also arranges dance courses.

content=An unofficial event held in late July or early August since 1997. The participants (yup, mostly males in their 20's) gather in Vantaa with rubber boats, rafts or whatever they can find that floats and travel downstreams towards Vanhankaupunki rapids while indulging beer - of course without life wests. This event has no official arrangers that could be held responsible if something happens as the date of the event just spreads in social media. If you think watching the spectacle isn't enough, remember that you're doing it on your own risk!

content=This is a huge park starting just north of the Olympic Stadium and extending northwards for 10 km. It encompasses an area of over 1,000 hectares. The park is mostly in a natural state, with plenty of walkways, bikeways, riding paths and sports facilities including Pirkkola Sports Park (ice hockey, swimming, running) and Paloheinä (skiing, golf). A popular jogging area.
content=A concert and exhibition hall in Kannelmäki.
content=A kind of a zoo with farm animals in a real countryside environment. Occasionally country music concerts are held at Haltiala.
directions=Malminkartano district, close to the Vantaa border

content=With a height of about 90 m, this is the highest point in Helsinki and when you've climbed the 426 stairs to the top you're rewarded with a nice view in all directions. In winter this is a great place for sledding. The hill itself is actually an old landfill and consists mostly of building material which has given the hill nicknames such as the dump hill or filling hill!

content=A bit outside the center but reachable by public transport, is Europe's biggest military surplus store. Has probably the friendliest and knowledgeable staff you'll find in Finland. Varusteleka sells anything from modern combat gear, to thirties Nazi leather trench coats, to very good value-for-money modern gore-tex hiking coats that some army somewhere had too many of.

In Vantaa and the northern suburbs there is no shortage of large shopping malls with even larger parking areas where you can buy everything from strawberries to washing machines. They also have other services like banks and restaurants and are all accessible by bus. The major ones are:
There's also a cluster of shopping malls in
, along freeway 45 south of Ring road III. On the Helsinki side, large shopping malls can be found in

The shopping centers in the district usually have a few cafés and restaurants where you can have a budget or mid-range meal during the day. In the evening you don't have to travel far to find a fast food joint or a Chinese or Middle Eastern restaurant. Self-catering is also an option.

value: name=IKEA furniture mall's cafe and restaurant
directions=at the intersection of freeway 4 and the third ring road

content=The furniture store IKEA has a restaurant on the 3rd floor and a café on the second where you can have a cheap and decent meal for well under €10 or a coffee or a hotdog for around €1. Also serves €2 breakfast in the morning except Sunday when the store is closed.
directions=a little over a kilometer west from Jumbo shopping center, best accessed by car
content=The "Lunch restaurant Ring Road Three" is a café all the day and serves you good all-you-can-eat buffet lunch at lunchtime. Popular among blue-collar workers.

content=The pizza buffet chain RAX has three restaurants in Vantaa. All you can eat buffet serving delicious (but some say "unhealthy") food such as pizza, chicken wings, lasagne, meat balls, fried onions, nachos, salads, soft drinks and ice for desert.
content=Sandwiches, pastries and cakes fresh out of the oven at the bakery's café.

content=A restaurant in the Flamingo entertainment center. The menu is along the line of steaks, chicken wings, large hamburgers etc. best enjoyed with a glass of wine from their surprisingly large wine list.
content=Thai food, as the name reveals.
content=Next to the former, the oldest Chinese restaurant in Vantaa.
content=Traditional Finnish food, the name translates to "at grandma's".

If you want fine dining, you should better travel to central Helsinki. The hotels near the airport also have their own restaurants, however the food at the hotel restaurants doesn't necessary live up to the prices.
Most suburbs have a pub or two. If you want something fancier, head to central Helsinki, that's what the locals also do.
The major hotel concentration in this part of the capital region is near the airport. No wonder, as most people coming to or leaving from Finland by air pass through Helsinki-Vantaa.

value: content=Best Western Hotel Haaga is centrally located since it's only 15 minutes drive from Helsinki-Vantaa airport.
directions=in the Tikkurila district of Vantaa
content=The national chain Sokos has a hotel in Tikkurila, next the railway station.
directions=Pakkala exit from Ring III Highway
content=Friendly family-owned hotel with basic but very clean and comfortable rooms. Restaurant, sauna (evening only), free shuttle service to airport (5-7 min).
content=Mid-range Finnish chain hotel, 10 min away by free shuttle bus. Renovated in 2007.

content=The only hotel located in the airport building itself, on the service floor of Terminal 2 and with direct indoor access from Terminal 1. Day rooms are also made available for use, depending on the booking situation, between 9:00 - 19:00.

content=Best Western Airport Hotel Pilotti is located in Vantaa, within 5-minute drive from Helsinki-Vantaa airport and within walking distance to Jumbo shopping centre and new Flamingo Spa. There is a regular bus service between Helsinki-Vantaa airport and the hotel.
content=Full-service hotel right next to the airport, opened in late 2007. Soundproof windows, bar, restaurant, sauna.
— 25 km further north where you can visit Ainola, the home of the famous composer Jean Sibelius.
